channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israel-Hamas War: U.N. Secretary General Calls for Cease-Fire as Israel Intensifies Airstrikes
item.description: The secretary general, António Guterres, said the massacres of Israelis by Hamas did not justify the “collective punishment” of civilians in Gaza, drawing a sharp rebuke from Israel.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Nuseirat Market, in the central Gaza Strip, was bombed by Israel on Saturday.

item.title: Coming of Age During the War in Ukraine
item.description: Each age group has suffered through the war, but for young adults it has been particularly hard — and not just for those who have served on the frontline.
item.dc:creator: Laetitia Vancon and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: War does not wait for young love to bloom.

item.title: Migrants Who Follow U.S. Entry Rules Faces Endless Wait
item.description: After surviving a perilous jungle, a mother and daughter obeyed the president’s plea to enter the United States legally. 341 days later, they’re still waiting.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Federico Rios
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sarah Cuauro at her home this month.

item.title: Amid Intense Fighting, Ukraine Orders Evacuation of Children
item.description: The evacuations from villages near the front line underscored the ferocity of the fighting as both Ukraine and Russia press bloody assaults.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mother and daughter waiting to be evacuated from Kupiansk Vuzlova, eastern Ukraine, last month. Evacuations often coincide with periods of particularly fierce fighting.

item.title: Israel Barrages Gaza With Airstrikes
item.description: Israel said it struck more than 400 targets in Gaza in its broadest single-day assault of the conflict. Palestinian officials said more than 700 were killed, the highest one-day toll of the war.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Farnaz Fassihi and Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourning relatives killed in an airstrike on Tuesday in Khan Younis, in the Gaza Strip, after an Israeli aerial bombardment that Israel said was the heaviest of the war, and that Gazan officials said was the deadliest.

item.title: Israel Prepares to Enter ‘Devil’s Playground’ of City Combat in Gaza
item.description: A ground invasion in Gaza could produce some of the fiercest street-to-street fighting since World War II.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: The aftermath of an Israeli strike in the Nuseirat market in central Gaza on Monday.

item.title: China Dismisses Gen. Li Shangfu, Its Defense Minister, Amid Speculation
item.description: The unexplained dismissal of Gen. Li Shangfu, the military’s top diplomat, came shortly after the foreign minister and two top commanders in the country’s rocket forces were also ousted.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.media:credit: How Hwee Young/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Chinese State Councilor and Minister of National Defence General Li Shangfu during a welcoming ceremony at a forum for regional officials in Singapore, in June.

item.title: Israel Says It Will Destroy Hamas. But Who Will Govern Gaza?
item.description: Israel has set itself a stiff challenge in aiming to vanquish Hamas. But an even bigger question looms: Once in Gaza, how and when does Israel get out?
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers taking part in an artillery drill in southern Israel on Monday.

item.title: At Least One Dead, Others Missing After Ships Collide in North Sea
item.description: Two cargo vessels collided in a busy shipping lane. At least one mariner is dead and several others are missing.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Dietmar Hasenpusch/DPA, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The 299-foot British cargo vessel Verity off Kiel, Germany, in 2014.

item.title: Jamaica Fears Brain Drain as Teachers Leave for U.S. Schools
item.description: Severe teacher shortages in the United States are prompting schools to recruit foreign teachers, sparking fears that education in Jamaica will suffer.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Alejandro Cegarra
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times

item.title: U.S. Politician Arrested at Hong Kong Airport for Gun in Luggage
item.description: A Washington state senator, Jeff Wilson, said he discovered the pistol on his flight and notified customs officials at the Hong Kong airport.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Joy Dong
item.media:credit: Anthony Kwan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Travelers at the Hong Kong International Airport, where a Washington State senator was arrested on Friday night.

item.title: War Has Smashed Assumptions About Israeli-Palestinian Conflict
item.description: Some paradigms taken for granted about Israel and the Palestinians, both in Gaza and the West Bank, have been broken. So has the idea that Washington can ignore the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A member of the Israeli special forces training in a mock Palestinian village outside Tse’elim, Israel, on Friday.

item.title: 5 Takeaways From Argentina’s Election
item.description: Javier Milei, a libertarian economist often compared to Donald Trump, will face off against Sergio Massa, Argentina’s economy minister, in a runoff next month.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Natalie Alcoba
item.media:credit: Tomas Cuesta/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Voters will decide between Sergio Massa, left, and Javier Milei in a runoff election next month.

item.title: Germany’s Far-Left Wagenknecht Forms New Populist Party
item.description: Sahra Wagenknecht has announced a new party, which could become another populist force scrambling German politics.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Annegret Hilse/Reuters
item.media:description: The leftist politician Sahra Wagenknecht has announced that she will form her own party.

item.title: 85-Year Old Israeli Hostage Held in Gaza Says She ‘Went Through Hell’
item.description: Yocheved Lifshitz offered the first public account to emerge from the more than 200 hostages estimated to be held in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Nadav Gavrielov
item.media:credit: Ariel Schalit/Associated Press
item.media:description: Yocheved Lifshitz at a hospital in Tel Aviv on Tuesday.

item.title: Macron Suggests an International Coalition to Fight Hamas During Israel Visit
item.description: The French president also suggested that the international coalition once deployed to fight the Islamic State could also fight Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Christophe Ena
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France, left, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in Jerusalem on Tuesday.

item.title: Several People Hospitalized in Austria After Taking Suspected Fake Ozempic
item.description: The drug, used to treat diabetes, has become popular as a weight loss treatment. Now, officials are warning of counterfeit versions circulating in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.category: Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency (Great Britain)
item.media:credit: Megan Jelinger/Reuters

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Israel ramps up Gaza strikes.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women mourning over the loss of those killed in the Israeli raids on of Deir al-Balah city from inside Shohadaa Al-Aqsa Hospital in the central Gaza Strip on Monday.

item.title: I.E.A. Sees Oil, Gas and Coal Demand Peaking By 2030
item.description: The prediction, which has stirred controversy among oil producers, is a sign of a sweeping transformation in the global energy landscape.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Naughton coal power plant in Kemmerer, Wyo., is slated to be decommissioned by 2025.

item.title: 13 Law Enforcement Officers Killed in Ambush in Mexico
item.description: The attack was in the Mexican state of Guerrero, which has been plagued by turf wars between drug cartels.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:credit: Francisco Robles/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Security officials recovering evidence at the site where 13 security officials were killed in an ambush by unidentified assailants in Coyuca de Benítez, in the state of Guerrero, Mexico, on Monday.

item.title: Israel Intensifies Strikes on Gaza as Its Allies Call for More Palestinian Aid
item.description: As two more hostages are released, American officials have urged Israel to delay a ground invasion, to allow time for negotiations and for more humanitarian aid to enter Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Alan Yuhas
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: A destroyed building in central Gaza on Monday.

item.title: Gaza Invasion Delays Raise Questions in Israel
item.description: So pervasive is the pall of chaos in Israel’s government that top officials saw fit to assure a traumatized public that they are “working in close and full cooperation, around the clock.”
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers cleaning the barrel of a tank on Saturday.

item.title: Nicola Sturgeon, Scotland’s Former Leader, Gets Driver’s License at 53
item.description: The former first minister, who resigned and quit as leader of the Scottish National Party before her arrest in June, said seeking a driver’s license at 53 had taken her out of her comfort zone.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:credit: Tolga Akmen/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Nicola Sturgeon, the former first minister of Scotland, said on Monday that she had passed her driving test for the first time.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Israel Intensifies Gaza Strikes
item.description: Plus the worldwide popularity of Lionel Messi’s pink jersey.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians carried children and their father from the Al-Zinati family, who were killed during Israeli air strikes in Khan Yunis in the southern Gaza Strip on Monday.

item.title: Train Collision in Bangladesh Leaves at Least 17 Dead
item.description: The accident, between a passenger train and a freight train, also injured over 100 people.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat
item.media:credit: Munir Uz Zaman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The site of a train collision in Bhairab, about 50 miles east of Dhaka, Bangladesh, on Monday.

item.title: Israel Shows Raw Footage From Hamas Attacks on Oct. 7
item.description: The Israeli military showed the compilation to foreign reporters on a day when Israel continued to bombard Gaza with heavy airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Photos of Israeli citizens who are being held hostage in Gaza are displayed in Tel Aviv on Saturday.

item.title: How the Israel-Hamas War Imperils Action Against Global Warming
item.description: Oil prices could surge. Disagreements between nations could worsen. The conflict complicates already fragile global diplomacy ahead of crucial climate talks.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta and Jim Tankersley
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers in the country’s south on Saturday. If war spreads it could hinder global cooperation on climate.

item.title: Turkey’s Erdogan Sends Sweden’s NATO Bid to Parliament for Ratification
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan had been holding out on approval of Sweden’s application. It’s unclear why he is now moving it forward.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
item.media:credit: Yves Herman/Reuters
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, left, with Prime Minister Ulf Kristersson of Sweden, right, and Jens Stoltenberg, the NATO secretary general, in Vilnius, Lithuania, in July.

item.title: Melting of West Antarctic Ice Shelves May Be Inevitable
item.description: It may be too late to halt the decline of the West Antarctic ice shelves, a study found, but climate action could still forestall the gravest sea level rise.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: NASA, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A satellite image of icebergs created when an Antarctic ice shelf collapsed.

item.title: Aleksei Navalny Forcibly Removed From Jail Cell After Protest
item.description: The Russian opposition leader had refused to leave his cell in protest after prison authorities took his writing tools, allies say.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Yulia Morozova/Reuters
item.media:description: The Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny appearing via video link in April at a hearing at a district court in Moscow.

item.title: Women in Iceland Go on Strike Against Gender Inequality
item.description: Organizers urged women and nonbinary people to stop all work on Tuesday. Even the prime minister said she would take part.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Jenny Gross
item.category: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development
item.media:credit: Arni Torfason/Associated Press
item.media:description: People from across Iceland gathered in Reykjavík for the one-day strike for gender equality on Tuesday.

item.title: Armita Geravand Reported Brain-Dead by Iran State Media
item.description: What happened to Armita Geravand, who entered a subway car and was carried out minutes later, is unclear. But her case evoked parallels to that of Mahsa Amini.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Leily Nikounazar

item.title: Kill and Be Killed: Ukraine’s Bloody Battlefield Equation
item.description: The dynamics of Europe’s deadliest war in generations remain exceedingly violent and increasingly complicated by factors far from the battlefield.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Constant Méheut
item.category: Center for Strategic and International Studies
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier wounded on the front line at Avdiivka was rushed for treatment last week in the Donetsk region of Ukraine.

item.title: The U.K. Wants a Cheaper Way to Handle Migrants. But Not This One.
item.description: Britain tested an alternative to detention for people living outside the immigration system. Though praised by the U.N., its outcomes didn’t fit the government’s hard-line approach.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I’ve been here over 13 years — 13 years of waiting and having my hands tied and being quiet.” A King’s Arms Project client who was brought to Bedfordshire, England, at the age of 13.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: Fears of a wider Middle East conflict.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers cleaning the barrel of a tank yesterday outside Be’eri, Israel.

item.title: Hamas Fails to Make Case That Israel Struck Hospital
item.description: A senior Hamas official says “nothing is left” of the munition that hit the Ahli Arab hospital in Gaza City last week, killing hundreds. Israel says the explosion was caused by a misfired Palestinian rocket.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Mohammed Saber/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The scene at Al Ahli hospital in Gaza on Wednesday. Hamas has yet to provide evidence to support its claim that an Israeli airstrike killed hundreds taking shelter there.

item.title: U.S. Advises Israel to Delay Gaza Invasion, Officials Say
item.description: The Biden administration has suggested that more time is needed for hostage negotiations, the delivery of aid to Palestinians and mapping out ways to avoid more civilian casualties.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Eric Schmitt, Michael D. Shear and Ronen Bergman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest for Israeli hostages in Tel Aviv on Saturday. The United States is hoping to buy more time for hostage negotiations, officials said.

item.title: Israelis and Gazans Flee Amid Warnings of Wider Regional War
item.description: Violence on Israel’s northern border with Lebanon, and strikes in Syria and the West Bank, sent shock waves through the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner, Raja Abdulrahim, Euan Ward and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers cleaning the barrel of a tank on Saturday outside Be’eri, Israel.

item.title: LinkedIn Issues Warning to Site Shaming Pro-Palestinian Sentiment
item.description: The site listed thousands of people and grouped them by their workplaces after they posted on the Israeli-Hamas conflict.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac
item.media:credit: John G Mabanglo/EPA, via Shutterstock

item.title: Monday Briefing: Israel Orders More Evacuations
item.description: Plus part one of our series, India’s Daughters.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Atef Safadi/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: An Israeli resident waited on the side of the road to evacuate to central and south Israel, in Kiryat Shmona, Israel, on Sunday.

item.title: Omer Balva, Israeli Reservist From Maryland, Is Killed Near Lebanon Border
item.description: Omer Balva, 22, was among the 360,000 reservists Israel had mobilized. He was near Israel’s northern border when his unit was struck by anti-tank missile fire, the Israeli military said.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Israel Defense Forces
item.media:description: Omer Balva moved to Israel after graduating from high school in Rockville, Md., in 2019.

item.title: Many Gazans in the North Say They Can’t Afford a Ride South
item.description: Israel continues to ramp up its calls for Gazans to evacuate, but the trip can cost hundreds of dollars, up from $3 a person before the war.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: The aftermath of an Israeli airstrike on Saturday evening, opposite a school where displaced people are sheltering in the southern Gazan city of Khan Younis.

item.title: Israel Strikes West Bank Mosque, Killing At Least 2
item.description: The Israeli military carried out a rare airstrike in the occupied West Bank, hitting a mosque in the Jenin refugee camp. Palestinian officials called the attack a “dangerous escalation.”
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner and Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Raneen Sawafta/Reuters

item.title: Israel Evacuates More Areas Near Lebanon Amid Hezbollah Clashes
item.description: The evacuation of Israeli towns and villages on the borders of Lebanon and Gaza amid escalating clashes is likely the largest in the country’s 75-year history, a local Israeli official said.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Jalaa Marey/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers accompanying a man to be evacuated from the northern Israeli town of Kiryat Shmona on Sunday.

item.title: Russian Missile Kills Six at Ukraine Postal Depot
item.description: The facility, on the outskirts of the eastern city of Kharkiv, was far from the front line but only about 20 miles from Russia’s border.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Sergey Bobok/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Police officers at the site of the strike.

item.title: Argentina Election Decides Between Javier Milei and Others
item.description: Javier Milei, a far-right libertarian, performed worse than polls predicted and will face Sergio Massa, Argentina’s economy minister, next month.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Luis Robayo/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Javier Milei greeting supporters after learning of the first results of the voting, in Buenos Aires on Sunday. He performed worse than the polls had predicted.

item.title: María Corina Machado Leads in Venezuela Primary to Oppose President Maduro
item.description: María Corina Machado, a center-right candidate, was leading in an election that showed voters’ faith in democracy and dissatisfaction with years of authoritarian rule.
item.dc:creator: Isayen Herrera and Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: María Corina Machado voted with her son and daughter in Caracas on Sunday. The election in this South American nation of roughly 28 million people took place with no official government support.

item.title: Peace Activists in Israel Renew Their Push for a Solution
item.description: Long derided as naïve, even traitors, the bridge builders between Israelis and Palestinians sense opportunity in the aftermath of the Hamas attack.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: The family of Awad Darawshe, who was killed by Hamas at a music festival, at their home in Iksal, Israel, on Friday. His sister Hayat sat at the far left, next to his mother, Hoda; his cousin Mousa; his father, Mousa; his sister Tansim; and his sister Maisam.

item.title: Israel and Ukraine Need the Same Three Weapons From the U.S.
item.description: Ukraine and Israel are fighting different kinds of wars, but some weapons systems could soon be in short supply if the fighting continues for months.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Artillery ammunition is needed by both Israel and Ukraine.

item.title: Inside the Commando Raids Unnerving Russia in Crimea
item.description: The lightning assaults are part of a larger campaign using drones and missiles to degrade Russian forces and demoralize the public.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian commandos known as Kukhar, left, 23, and Askold, 38, who conceal their identities, met to describe a raid on Crimea, in a bare office used as a safe house in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital.

item.title: Anthony Albanese to Visit Xi Jinping as China-Australia Tensions Ease
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said he would visit China and meet with Xi Jinping, another sign of a thaw in the countries’ once-icy relations.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Harvesting grapes at a vineyard in the Riverland region of South Australia in March. Chinese tariffs have crushed Australia’s wine industry for three years.

item.title: U.S. Deploys Missile Systems to Mideast After Iran Threats
item.description: The latest deployment is in response to growing threats from Iran and its allies in the region. President Biden has warned Iran to not join the war against Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Andrés R. Martínez
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Zarpanews/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The aircraft carrier U.S.S. Eisenhower in Greece in 2021.

item.title: Drought in Spain Leaves Villagers Fearing a Drier Future
item.description: Residents of Pozoblanco and 22 other villages in the country’s south have had to get their drinking water from tankers since April, when the reservoir serving the area dried up.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Chaundler
item.media:credit: Rachel Chaundler for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tanker trucks have been deployed to drought-affected areas of southern Spain to deliver 180,000 liters of potable water a day to approximately 80,000 residents.

item.title: Indigenous Australians Say ‘Reconciliation Is Dead’ After ‘Voice’
item.description: The rejection of the Indigenous Voice to Parliament is likely to lead to an irreversible shift in the nation’s relationship with its first peoples.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Lukas Coch/Australian Associated Press, via Reuters
item.media:description: From left, the flag of the Torres Strait Islands, the Aboriginal flag and the Australian flag, in Canberra this month.

item.title: First Humanitarian Aid Reaches a Hard-Pressed Gaza
item.description: But the 20-truck shipment of food, water and medical supplies is only a fraction of what is needed to head off a catastrophe, officials say.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Fuller and Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Twenty trucks carried humanitarian supplies into the Gaza Strip from Egypt on Saturday, but aid agencies said far more would be needed for Gaza’s two million residents.

item.title: How Hamas Came to Release 2 U.S. Hostages Back to Israel
item.description: It took American and Qatari diplomacy, and self-interested decisions by Hamas, to bring two hostages safely back to Israel.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman, Adam Goldman, Edward Wong and Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: U.S. Embassy in Jerusalem, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An image released by the American government shows the freed American hostages Judith Raanan, right, and her daughter Natalie Raanan, speaking by phone to President Biden on Friday.

item.title: Peace Summit in Egypt Shows a Shift in Rhetoric but no Consensus
item.description: World leaders met in Cairo on Saturday to talk about de-escalating violence in Gaza. Hours later, they were still deeply divided.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Khaled Desouki/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt opened a summit of world leaders in Cairo on Saturday.

item.title: Peter Nygard Lured Women to His Office’s Bedroom, Witnesses Testified
item.description: Five women accusing Peter Nygard of sexual assault completed their testimonies this week as prosecutors prepare to close their case in Toronto.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai

item.title: New Evidence Found of Rape and Torture by Russian Forces in Ukraine
item.description: A U.N. report documented cases in the southern regions of Kherson and Zaporizhzhia, which remain partly under Moscow’s control.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cell at a prison in Kherson, Ukraine, where Russian forces held and tortured captives.

item.title: Russians Who Moved to Israel to Escape Ukraine War Are in the Middle of Another One
item.description: Thousands of citizens with Jewish heritage left for Israel after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Alexander Zemlianichenko/Associated Press
item.media:description: People gathering at a solidarity service for Israeli victims of the Hamas attacks at the Jewish Museum and Tolerance Center in Moscow last week.

item.title: Fear Grows in Israel for Sick or Wounded Hostages
item.description: Hamas released two American hostages on Friday, but concern is rising about the hundreds still held in Gaza, especially the injured and ill.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Adam Sella
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli soldier taping a photograph of her friend Ron Sherman to a wall near the Israeli Ministry of Defense in Tel Aviv.
